title: Array Fundamentals
content: Arrays are a fundamental data structure that stores elements in contiguous memory locations. Each element can be accessed directly using an index. Arrays have O(1) access time but fixed size.

title: Array Operations
content: Common array operations include insertion deletion searching and sorting. Insertion and deletion at the end are O(1) but in the middle require shifting elements.

title: Linked List Introduction
content: A linked list is a linear data structure where elements are stored in nodes and each node points to the next node. Unlike arrays linked lists have dynamic size and no random access.

title: Tree Data Structure
content: A tree is a hierarchical data structure with a root node and child nodes. Each node can have multiple children making it useful for representing hierarchical relationships.

title: Binary Trees
content: A binary tree is a tree where each node has at most two children called left and right child. Binary trees are fundamental for many algorithms and data structures.

title: Graph Fundamentals
content: A graph is a collection of vertices connected by edges. Graphs can be directed or undirected and are used to model relationships between objects.
